TopicTitle: What is happening here with the science processing?

Articles.Content:
is this just some display change in 1.1? Does it display the total science that can be generated rather than the data? makes it hard when you can only have 500 data.

Also some of my experiments display --- as the value... is that for exps that have already been processed in the lab?

I haven't messed with the labs in 1.1 yet, so I can't say for sure. But by looking at your screenshot and from reading the changelog I think you're right. 

It's displaying the end amount of science points you'll get from that one experiment (304 x 5 = 1520). Looks like it also tells you how long it'll take. I'm assuming that you already have an experiment in there, and adding this one will take it to 705 total data? 

Also, each lab can now hold 750 data instead of 500.

Can't help with the ones where there is no value given, sorry.

Yes, this is a big display change for 1.1.

Yes, "--" is for experiments that have already been processed. 750 units of data to max out the buffer. You currently had 401.7 out of 750, as the MPL display said. 401 + 304 = 705, so the experiment you are looking at can load successfully.

And you can still load an infinite number of experiments into the lab for later processing. But if you take the lab out of the SOI of the experimented-on object before doing the processing, you lose a 40% science bonus.

Also, another "gotcha" that I didn't find out until too late (for that mission):  there's another science-lab change.  When you press the "research" button to add it to the lab as data... it consumes the experiment and it's now gone.  So you can't then return the experiment for more science points, unless you go out and get an extra copy to take back.
@Snark yeah, that was an intentional change, was talked about in one of the dev notes, and was in the changelog.

9 minutes ago, FullMetalMachinist said:

@Snark yeah, that was an intentional change, was talked about in one of the dev notes, and was in the changelog. 

Well, yes, I wasn't calling it a bug. 

Just that it caught me by surprise, is all.  There were a lot of changes in 1.1, and that one kinda got lost in the shuffle for me.  If somebody is having some post-1.1 growing pains with the MPL, it's a difference worth mentioning.

1 hour ago, Snark said:

Well, yes, I wasn't calling it a bug. 

Just that it caught me by surprise, is all.  There were a lot of changes in 1.1, and that one kinda got lost in the shuffle for me.  If somebody is having some post-1.1 growing pains with the MPL, it's a difference worth mentioning.

Fair enough, there were a few things that 1.1.X caught me by surprise as well. Just making sure that any cries of "there be bugs here" were kept in check.

Since I had just done a lot of testing on MPLs in 1.0.5, I did the same set of tests during beta testing. Lots and lots of changes, indeed. The big one for me is that you can't cheat on Kerbin anymore. It used to be in 1.0.5 that if you got the MPL one meter off the ground, then you no longer suffered the "landed at Kerbin" penalty. But now you have to get them all the way to orbit.

Gah, it consumes the data? I didn't even realize that...  good thing I found out now, before i send my eve lander backup... I have duplicates... but I planned to transmit one, return hte other.... except.... wait... can I store data in the mk1 crew cabin? I may not be able to take 2 copies up (my final ascent vehicle is a mk1 pod and mk1 crew cabin, for 3 kerbals total)
Crew cabins and mk1 pods can both store one copy of the data. So xmit one, put one in an mpl, and return one.

Well, I have 2 mat bays, and 2 goo pods, and storage for 2 experiments. I'll run them both at flying low, but then I need to reset them to take the surface readings... and they are dropped before ascent.

So now I need to decide between return 2, return 1 + transmit one, or return 1 + process 1.

Once on the surface, I can transmit data for the surface as much as I want as I've got a scientist to reset it... I can still only take 2 copies back to orbit. For the surface I need to decide between So now I need to decide between return 2, or return 1 + process 1.

@KerikBalm: Are you willing to send your scientist out on EVA to grab one copy of the data and reset the experiments while your stuff is slowly floating down the last thousand meters on its parachutes?

Or even more so: take all your experiments flying high. Once the parachutes are out: EVA the scientist, grab all the data, restore all 4, grab one set of data (flying low), reset one more time, store copies in the crew cabin, board the pod, and run all the experiments once more before touchdown? (lol -- I think I'm gonna try that just to see how well it works.)

Edited May 23, 2016 by bewing

The science pods, while attached to the vehicle, cannot be reached by the scientist unless in space/very high in the atmosphere in near vacuum conditions.

Once landed, they decouple and land nearby with parachutes and sepratrons... the scientist goes and takes the data then, and then operates additional experiments while getting the surface sample too.

I'would need to send another lander to get additional copies of the flying low data... the science pods can't be taken back into orbit.
